TITLE: Why a Rhodes Scholar’s Ambition Led Her to a Job at Starbucks
SUMMARY: Jaz Brisack became a barista for the same reasons that talented young people have long chosen their career paths: a mix of idealism and ambition.

TITLE: Apple Workers at Maryland Store Vote to Unionize, a First in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Roughly two-thirds of employees at the store in Towson, Md., voted to join the union.

TITLE: How Work-From-Home Setups Have Changed
SUMMARY: Hybrid or remote work is settling in as a permanent reality for millions. Their setups and technical skills can still feel like a temporary solution.

TITLE: The Week in Business: The Fed Goes Big
SUMMARY: It was a rocky week in the financial markets and for cryto. Elon Musk met with Twitter employees. And there are signs of a slowdown in real estate.

TITLE: ‘Lightyear’ Opens at No. 2, as ‘Jurassic World’ Holds Strong
SUMMARY: The Pixar movie’s estimated $51 million in North American sales fell short of expectations.

TITLE: Tattoo Artists Face a Grayer Palette in Europe
SUMMARY: The E.U. has prohibited some pigments, deeming them potentially hazardous to humans. Artists and manufacturers around the world are struggling to find replacements.

TITLE: Bitcoin Plummets Below $20,000 for First Time Since Late 2020
SUMMARY: Its fall was accelerated in recent weeks by the collapse of two major cryptocurrency projects while sowing doubts about the stability of the overall cryptocurrency market.

TITLE: Inflation Expected to Remain High Even as Economy Slows and Layoffs Rise
SUMMARY: Inflation is expected to remain high later this year even as the economy slows and layoffs rise. Already, signs of financial stress are surfacing.

TITLE: How to Think About E.S.G. Investing in a Falling Market
SUMMARY: Mr. Musk trashed E.S.G. investing. The S.E.C. is investigating Goldman Sachs’s move into the sector. In a falling market, what should investors consider?

TITLE: Gun Control Advocates Have More Money Now, but Money Can’t Buy Zeal
SUMMARY: After more mass shootings, one side is gaining donors and political will; the other is galvanized by gun rights. Will anything be different?

TITLE: Fathers on Playing Video Games With Their Children
SUMMARY: “You can learn a lot from video games: hand-eye coordination and being able to lose.” Fathers talk gaming with their children.

TITLE: ‘The Dirty Secret of Covid’: Scott Galloway on the Postpandemic Economic Turmoil
SUMMARY: Mr. Galloway, an outspoken N.Y.U. professor, speaks with DealBook about the crypto crash and what Silicon Valley will look like on the other side.

TITLE: Gun Sellers Stoke Fears to Boost Weapon Sales
SUMMARY: The number of firearms in the U.S. is outpacing the country’s population, as an emboldened gun industry and its allies target buyers with rhetoric of fear, machismo and defiance.

TITLE: French Nuclear Power Crisis Frustrates Europe’s Push to Quit Russian Energy
SUMMARY: France typically exports electricity, but now it risks blackouts and a need for imported power because of problems at the state nuclear operator.

TITLE: Help! It’s Been More Than 2 Years and I Still Don’t Have the Refund
SUMMARY: Our columnist has received many reader emails complaining of tour operators and travel agencies dragging their feet on refunds for trips or other services. He investigates a $334 fare with Euro Railways.

TITLE: Huge Fire Breaks Out at Sinopec’s Shanghai Complex, Leaving 1 Dead
SUMMARY: Firefighters were able to put the blaze under control, but it caused residents of a nearby neighborhood to flee their homes.

TITLE: Starbucks Executive, Prominent in Push Against Union Drive, Will Leave
SUMMARY: Rossann Williams, president of retail for North America, will depart after 17 years at the company, which said she declined a new position with Starbucks.

TITLE: TikTok says its American traffic is going through Oracle servers, but it retains backups.
SUMMARY: The app is trying to convince the U.S. government that it won’t expose Americans’ information to China.

TITLE: W.T.O. Agrees to Limited Relaxing of Patent Protections on Covid Vaccines
SUMMARY: The agreement is a limited measure that is likely to have little impact on global vaccine supply.

TITLE: How Founders Decide What They Should Get Paid
SUMMARY: Whether in a downturn or when things are flush, the compensation that start-up founders give themselves always sends some kind of message.

TITLE: Covid Vaccine and Fisheries Deals Close a ‘Roller Coaster’ W.T.O. Meeting
SUMMARY: Members of the global trade group were forced to scale back plans for more ambitious agreements, but they were ultimately able to reach several deals at a meeting in Geneva.

TITLE: Tether: The Coin That Could Wreck Crypto
SUMMARY: As cryptocurrencies have plunged, attention has focused on a potential point of vulnerability: the market’s reliance on a so-called stablecoin called Tether.

TITLE: Infighting Overshadows Big Plans at The Washington Post
SUMMARY: The aim of Sally Buzbee, The Post’s editor, is to broaden the newspaper’s reach. A year into the job, she’s dealing with internal tumult over some longstanding grievances.

TITLE: Vince McMahon Steps Down From W.W.E. Amid Misconduct Investigation
SUMMARY: Mr. McMahon, the pro wrestling company’s chairman and chief executive, agreed to pay a secret settlement to an employee with whom he was said to have had an affair, The Wall Street Journal reported this week.

TITLE: Tracking the Fear Index on Wall Street
SUMMARY: Plus, with Revlon’s bankruptcy, Wall Street bankers get ready for a wave of distressed situations.

TITLE: Why Some States Are Expanding Tax-Free Periods
SUMMARY: The “holidays” are aimed at helping consumers, but they’re also politically attractive. Tax experts say they provide only modest benefits.

TITLE: Wall Street Has Its Worst Week Since March 2020
SUMMARY: The selling was fueled by persistently high inflation and fears that the Fed’s efforts to tame it with higher interest rates will choke growth.

TITLE: Dozens Injured by Hot Coals at Company Event in Zurich
SUMMARY: More than two dozen employees of a Swiss company were injured while walking in bare feet over hot coals, an ancient religious tradition that has become popular on corporate retreats.

TITLE: As Some Office Workers Return, Happy Hour Sees a Wobbly Comeback
SUMMARY: Even as companies struggle to coax employees back to the office, some bars report that their after-work crowds are nearing prepandemic levels.

TITLE: How Can You Travel for $100 or Less a Day? Get a Cruise Deal.
SUMMARY: As companies bring their full fleets back online, many ships still have room. That means bargains are being offered outside the winter “wave season,” making some sailings unexpectedly cheap, even in an era of inflation.

TITLE: SpaceX Said to Fire Employees Involved in Letter Rebuking Elon Musk
SUMMARY: In an email, Gwynne Shotwell, SpaceX’s president, said the letter had made other employees “feel uncomfortable, intimidated and bullied.”

TITLE: Trial of New Alzheimer’s Drug Reports Disappointing Results
SUMMARY: The drug, crenezumab, failed to prevent early symptoms or slow cognitive decline, the latest setback in the long quest to find effective therapies for the disease.

TITLE: BuzzFeed News Names Karolina Waclawiak as Top Editor
SUMMARY: Karolina Waclawiak, its executive editor of culture, takes over the newsroom at a difficult moment for the digital media company.

TITLE: Sales at Art Basel Fair Don’t Show Signs of Downturn
SUMMARY: In the first full in-person fair in its usual June slot since 2019, Art Basel saw numerous big-ticket items sell, including a $40 million Louise Bourgeois spider.

TITLE: In Twitter Meeting, Elon Musk Fields Questions From 8,000 Employees
SUMMARY: Mr. Musk answered questions from Twitter’s 8,000 workers for the first time in a virtual meeting on Thursday.

TITLE: Mortgage Rates Jump to 5.78 Percent, Rising at the Fastest Pace Since 1987
SUMMARY: The climb in mortgage rates, coupled with skyrocketing home prices, has eroded what prospective home buyers can afford.

TITLE: USA Today to Remove 23 Articles After Investigation Into Fabricated Sources
SUMMARY: The articles were removed after an investigation identified stories with sources that appeared to be fabricated, USA Today said.

TITLE: Abbott Baby Formula Plant Again Stops Production, This Time Because of Flooding
SUMMARY: Severe storms flooded parts of the facility in Sturgis, Mich., which went offline in February over contamination concerns, exacerbating a nationwide formula shortage.

TITLE: Ford recalls 2.9 million vehicles over a flaw in securing the gear shift in park.
SUMMARY: Regulators said 1 percent of the vehicles recalled could have the defect. The products affected include 1.7 million Escape S.U.V.s.

TITLE: Revlon Files for Bankruptcy
SUMMARY: The company has struggled to attract younger shoppers who are choosing celebrity makeup lines like those from Kylie Jenner and Rihanna.

TITLE: Musk to Address Twitter All-Hands Meeting
SUMMARY: Musk will take questions from employees as his $44 billion acquisition of the company moves ahead, despite his hand-wringing about bots.

TITLE: Bank of England, fearing persistent inflation, raises rates yet again.
SUMMARY: Price pressures are reaching deeper into the British economy, the bank said, as it raised its benchmark rate to 1.25 percent.

TITLE: Germany Appeals to Save Gas After Russia Tightens Flows
SUMMARY: Germany’s economy minister accused Vladimir Putin of trying to raise natural gas prices. Italy, Austria and the Czech Republic also reported gas cuts.

TITLE: Six Takeaways From the Fed’s Meeting on Interest Rates
SUMMARY: The central bank took its most aggressive step yet to try to tame rapid and persistent inflation, raising interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point.

TITLE: Stock Markets Fall After Fed Rally Fades
SUMMARY: Stocks tumbled, with the S&P 500 falling further into bear market territory, as investors focused on the threat that inflation and higher interest rates pose to the economy.

TITLE: Ukraine’s Highly Mobile Tech Work Force Hits the Road
SUMMARY: How one Lithuanian company evacuated dozens of employees, three dogs and one guinea pig as Russia invaded.

TITLE: Bear Markets and Recessions Happen More Often Than You Think
SUMMARY: The U.S. has been in recession 14 percent of the time since World War II. But being prepared can minimize hardship and even offer investing opportunities.

TITLE: Dog Owners Want More Space. Here’s Where They’re Finding It.
SUMMARY: Areas with homes that have pet-friendly features and are close to a dog park are in hot demand, a new analysis shows.

TITLE: A Chinese City May Have Used a Covid App to Block Protesters
SUMMARY: People from across China had set off for the city of Zhengzhou to protest the freezing of their savings. Then they were prevented from moving freely.

TITLE: Infants Died in Fisher-Price Seats That Are Not for Sleep, Safety Commission Said
SUMMARY: The deaths of at least 13 children were associated with the Infant-to-Toddler or Newborn-to-Toddler rockers sold by the company. Congress had outlawed sleepers with an incline.

TITLE: A Rapper’s Delight: Hip-Hop Memorabilia Goes Up for Auction
SUMMARY: Original vinyl records, turntables and other ephemera belonging to the hip-hop pioneer D.J. Kool Herc will be included in a sale at Christie’s.

TITLE: What the Fed’s Rate Hike Means for Credit Cards and Student Loans
SUMMARY: Consumers can expect to pay more for some of life’s most common kinds of borrowing.

TITLE: What the Fed’s Rate Hike Means for Mortgages
SUMMARY: Rates on 30-year fixed mortgages track the yield on 10-year Treasury bonds, which are influenced by inflation and the Fed’s actions, among other things.

TITLE: Internet Explorer Is Shutting Down in a Burst of Nostalgia
SUMMARY: Microsoft will be disabling IE and directing Windows users to its modern Edge web browser in coming months. The news inspired jokes, memes and even some fond memories.

TITLE: Inside Kraken’s Culture War Stoked by Its C.E.O.
SUMMARY: Jesse Powell, who leads the crypto exchange Kraken, has challenged the use of preferred pronouns, debated who can use racial slurs and called American women “brainwashed.”

TITLE: Russia tightens gas supplies to Germany and Italy.
SUMMARY: Germany says Gazprom aims to drive up fuel prices.
